Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hydraulic Control and Mixing of the Deep Ocean Flow through the Samoan Passage
Award.AbstractNarration:
The large-scale circulation of the ocean also known as the Meridional Overturning Circulation (MOC) comprises a series of shallow and deep water currents that transport mass, heat, carbon, and nutrients around the globe. The Samoan Passage, which carries the majority of the transport in its deep northward branch, is an important element of the Pacific Ocean circulation system. Recent observations supported by a previously funded NSF project have identified a previously unknown split of the flow between a deeper eastern channel and multiple shallower, western pathways within the Samoan Passage complex. Additional changes such as a warming and weakening of the flow through the passage have also been observed over the past twenty years, which supports the need for long-term observations. This project will examine the dynamics of the flow through the Samoan Passage in detail using a combination of observations, theory and numerical models. Currently, there are no deep ocean monitoring system deployed in the Pacific MOC and this project has the potential to aid in the development of an observing system that can complement the one currently deployed in the Atlantic. Climate models predict a weakening of the global overturning circulation, which could be confirmed or refuted with these observing systems. The knowledge gained from the proposed work can likely be applied to similar deep passages and fracture zones around the world. Two early career scientists, summer undergraduates, a graduate student and a post-doctoral researcher will gain valuable training in modern methods used in oceanography through this project. Diverse outreach activities are planned to engage the public with the results and knowledge gained from this project through collaborations with a modern dance company, and the Birch Aquarium and a high school in San Diego.

Extensive measurements collected under previous NSF funding, including a combination of moored time series and deep towed measurements will be used to study hydraulic effects on the flow in the Samoan Passage. Strong turbulent mixing was observed as the flow passes through and over various constrictions and sills, thereby substantially altering its water mass characteristics. The recent measurements indicate hydraulic criticality of the flow through the Samoan Passage, at least at one major sill. The three specific objectives of this project include: investigating the influence of hydraulic processes on mixing and friction at various sills, studying hydraulic criticality and implications for transport and partition of the flow through and around the Samoan Passage, and informing an efficient monitoring strategy for the flow through the Samoan Passage. As a result of this project, hydraulic theory will be improved and observationally validated, making it applicable to dense overflows in other passages and to the flow in the multitude of fracture zones that are believed to be important drivers for abyssal upwelling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The majority of the lower limb of the Pacific Ocean overturning circulation, a current system important for the global climate system due to its role in the meridional and vertical transport of heat, freshwater, and tracers like carbon dioxide, passes through the Samoan Passage near 9?S, 178?W. Several channels, collectively termed Samoan Passage, provide a pathway for northward flowing abyssal waters originating from polar regions through a submarine ridge system spanning from Fiji to Tahiti in the equatorial South Pacific. As the flow is funneled through these various channels, it undergoes strong turbulent mixing with ambient waters; processes that are understood to be important in closing the loop of the overturning circulation cell. A previous NSF-funded project provided a rich observational dataset on the detailed flow through the Samoan Passage. In this project, this dataset was combined with numerical models and novel theoretical developments to better understand the dynamic response of the large scale flow to the interaction with the Samoan Passage channel system, and to study the dynamics of water mass transformation within the Samoan Passage through turbulent mixing in detail.

The project revealed that turbulent mixing within the Samoan Passage is intricately coupled to local bathymetric features and relatively independent, within the observational limits, of the overall strength of the flow through the Samoan Passage. The evolving picture is thus one of constant water mass modification driven by flow-topography interactions. However, an analysis of the physical processes occurring near and especially downstream of topographic features indicates that the overall thickness of the abyssal layer flowing through the Samoan Passage matters for the strength of the turbulent mixing. This dependence has potential implications for future climate states as several observational studies have shown a general contraction of the abyssal layer in the Pacific Ocean.

Observations and simple numerical simulations showed that the physical processes leading to mixing near topography in the Samoan Passage resemble downslope winds found in atmospheric studies of mountain lee waves. The temporal and lateral scales of these processes are generally too small to be resolved by general ocean circulation and climate models. Attempts were made to model the impacts of these processes on the energy and momentum budgets of the abyssal flow based on more easily accessible large scale flow parameters with the goal of improving the representation of turbulent mixing and water mass transformation in afore mentioned coarse numerical models.

Hydraulically controlled flow at several sills within the Samoan Passage, physically similar to weir flow, blocks some of the incoming flow and diverts it to the east of the Samoan Passage around the Manihiki Plateau. Theoretical models reveal that turbulent mixing and friction within the Samoan Passage are essential for the division of the flow between the two flow paths. As the flow around the Manihiki Plateau is less constricted and therefore less prone to turbulent mixing and the associated water mass modification, this has important implications for abyssal dynamics of the Pacific Ocean, especially under a possibly varying ratio of the flow division in a changing climate.

General aspects of physical oceanography and the specific importance of the flow through the Samoan Passage were taught to 5th and 6th grade students through a dance class in collaboration with the non-profit organization A Step Beyond. Led by Larry Pratt (WHOI) and dance teacher Roxanne Rojas de Blanco, the students developed a dance choreography based on the learning material. A visit of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography campus, combined with a hands-on fluid mechanics lab experiment, further engaged the students and raised their interest in STEM research in general and physical oceanography specifically.
